key_points: Ten Republicans, including Rep. Tom Rice and Rep. Liz Cheney, voted with Democrats to impeach Trump on charges of "incitement of insurrection."
This small group of Republicans represents a wide ideological spectrum within the party.
The bipartisan nature of the vote could help impeachment gain traction in the Senate.
Many Republicans who voted for impeachment called it a vote of conscience.
Some of Trump's allies, like Rep. Jim Jordan, downplayed the significance, maintaining Trump's strong support.
Others, like Rep. Garland "Andy" Barr, argued the GOP's hesitance was due to concerns about the impeachment process and the political climate.
Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell expressed openness to conviction but has not made a final decision.
Several Senate Republicans, including Sen. Patrick J. Toomey and Sen. Ben Sasse, voiced concerns over Trump's role in the Capitol riot and his election fraud claims.
The impeachment now moves to the Senate for trial, with some Republicans signaling a willingness to convict.
The division among Republicans reflects broader concerns about the party's future and Trump's role.
spokespersons: Rep. Tom Rice (House Republican from South Carolina)
